text: this this skirt steak-- it might look a
little awkward for the grill but it
chars beautifully it's so succulent and
it's a great alternative to flank steak
and if it actually is too big for your
grill just do this perfect skirt steak
loves to be seasoned ahead it really
soaks up the flavors so I'm gonna make a
little herb paste here I've got some
lemon thyme and some garlic which is
gonna give it great flavor by the way if
you don't have lemon thyme regular time
is great it could also use tarragon or
oregano scallions give you a very green
color for this and a lot of onion flavor
I've got some basil leaves now I have a
secret ingredient here I have
pepperoncini probably the last time you
saw one of these was in an antipasto
platter in an Italian restaurant these
are great to have around because not
only do they add heat they also add a
light pickle flavor but if you don't
have them you could use maybe a jalapeno
and some pickle juice or even a little
slice of pickle you just want to chop
them up and take out the stem and then
I'm gonna use some lemon zest if you're
using regular time you might want to use
two lemons but since I've got lemon
thyme I'm gonna use one lemon and I'm
gonna juice half of my lemon right in
here the acid helps tenderize the meat
so if you didn't bring out your lemon
squeezer here is a little trick to
getting rid of the seeds just hold your
hand right over its gonna catch any
seeds and now I'm gonna start blending
it up once you've got everything chopped
up that's when you add the oil and
that's going to help really reduce it to
a paste
I forgot to salt it so I'm just gonna
stir my salt in right here I have a lot
of it because steak needs a lot of salt
for flavor usually the rule of thumb
with salt and steak is you want about a
teaspoon per pound of meat a little less
maybe if you don't like things quite as
seasoned now I'm just gonna slather it
on the thing about seasoning up a steak
ahead of time especially skirt steak is
that the more intense your seasonings
the less amount of time you really need
to let it sit so this is pretty intense
I can get away with just leaving this
for maybe half an hour in the fridge
you'll be fine but what's nice is I do
this and then I light my grill and by
the time the grill is really nice and
hot the steaks are ready steaks ready
grill is ready it's gonna wipe off a
little of the excess green basically
because I don't want it to drip down
into the coals and possibly cause a
flare-up see if you cut it in half it
fits and if you have one of those little
mini grills you can even cut it in
quarters you don't want to let this go
too long skirt steak is best served rare
so while this is grilling don't move it
I really believe that you should just
let it get nice and charred on one side
and then flip it to the other side I
know there are people out there who
disagree with me so you can do it your
way but I'm doing it my way
these babies are done just gonna cover
them for a few minutes so that they can
reabsorb some of those juices now after
cooking the skirt steak until it's just
rare the second most important part of
serving skirt steak is carving it
properly
you want to make sure that you're
cutting across the grain and not with
the grain if you see these little
stripes these are muscle fibers you want
to separate them because if you cut with
the grain you're gonna give somebody a
big mouthful of chewy muscle if you cut
across it you're gonna get a very
succulent tender piece of steak so watch
what not to do don't do this see how
you're getting all that grain and here's
what you should do take your knife at a
45 degree angle and then you just want
to cut right across the grain see that
makes her much better eating
so after you carve a skirt steak you're
gonna end up with a couple of little
straggly bits but you know what those
are the very best part
Oh
